typeData.textContent:
This psychology course will introduce you to some of the major research areas within the field of psychology: the scientific study of behaviour.  The course begins with an overview of psychology and its research methods, and then covers several fundamental topics in psychology such as biological psychology, learning and memory, and conscious states.

This section of PSYC101 is a 3-credit online distance education course.  It has both synchronous (live; e.g., Q&A sessions, discussion sessions, and group activities) and asynchronous  components (not live; e.g., prerecorded lectures, online quizzes, and self-assessments).  Because it is a distance education course, most course-related activities are asynchronous.

The course uses an open-source text that is supplemented by many video-based lectures and online resources. In addition, the course contains interviews with some leading research psychologists and some educational animations.

There are no prerequisites or corequisites for this course.  Note that you cannot receive credit for both PSYC101 and PSYC100.

nodes.title: Anatomy of a Typical Synapse (Alyssa Juma)
Week 7 – The Epigenetics of Childhood Trauma (Sherry Wang)

typeData.textContent:
Some external factors such as diet, drugs and chemicals are capable of turning genes on or off without modifying the basic DNA sequences. Such changes in gene expression are heritable and can be passed on to several generations. This is the so-called epigenetics.

There is a series of studies showing that epigenetics plays an important role in the persisting effects of early experiences. Serious stressors, especially early in life, can change the phenotypes and have long-lasting effects on both physical and mental health. Much of this work was done by Michael Meaney and his colleagues at McGill University.

Maternal behaviors in rats

Their first experiment examines the effects that different mothering styles have on baby rats. There are two groups of mother rats, one spends much time licking their pups, which is called “high lickers”, whereas the other one spends little time doing so, which is called “low lickers”. The researchers found that highly licked rat pups are much less fearful and have better control of stress as adults when placed in a stressful environment. The rising level of serotonin in pups leads to a decrease in DNA methylation, which regulates the level of cortisol, a stress hormone, and helps them to get back to normal quickly.

Childhood abuse

Such long-term impact of childhood experiences not only exists in rats but also humans. In a recent study, Meaney’s team extracted the hippocampal samples of 12 men who committed suicide when they were 35 years old and had the experience of childhood abuse, and 12 men who committed suicide when they were 35 years old but with no experience of childhood abuse. The researchers separated them into two groups and compared each group with a control group of 12 men who died at around the same age but had no experience of abuse and suicide. The results showed that the level of DNA methylation of the group who had a history of abuse and committed suicide had increased compared to others, while there was no significant difference between the other two groups, regardless of whether they died of suicide.

To sum up, childhood trauma can actually influence our gene expression and result in a higher risk of developing mental and physical health problems later in life. Therefore, adults should endeavor to create a safe and warm family environment, which will protect not only their children but also the following generations.

Reference

https://www.psychologytoday.com/ca/blog/psyched/201909/the-epigenetics-childhood-trauma-0

https://www.mcgill.ca/newsroom/channels/news/childhood-trauma-has-life-long-effect-genes-and-brain-104667

McGowan, P. O., Sasaki, A., D’Alessio, A. C., Dymov, S., Labonté, B., Szyf, M., Turecki, G., & Meaney, M. J. (2009). Epigenetic regulation of the glucocorticoid receptor in human brain associates with childhood abuse. Nature neuroscience, 12(3), 342–348. https://doi.org/10.1038/nn.2270

nodes.title: Sleep Disorder: Narcolepsy - Review (Nathalie Lam)
nodes.description: This node provides a review on the sleep disorder, narcolepsy.

typeData.textContent:
Sleep is an essential human need, like drinking and breathing. During sleep, our body is working to support healthy brain function and maintain physical health. Sleep deprivation and deficiency can lead to physical and mental problems. When we experience a poor-quality sleep, we will feel exhausted rather than refreshed. So, how can sleep play a role in the clear mind?

We know that nutrients supply and waste clearance are necessary all over the body. Our blood vessels and lymphatic system are working to support energy and dispose waste, respectively. But there are no lymphatic vessels in the brain, instead, the brain waste is cleaned by Cerebral spinal fluid (CSF). CSF is a watery liquid that is continuously produced and absorbed and that flows in the ventricles within the brain and around the surface of the brain and spinal cord (William, 2018). It flows in, washing through your brain in rhythmic, pulsing waves. By imaging the brain of living mice, CSF was pumped back into and through the brain along the outsides of the blood vessels to clean waste (Iliff, 2014). Interestingly, these CSF dynamics only appear during non-rapid eye movement sleep (Fultz et al., 2019).

Sleep problem causes a disruption of normal CSF circulation, which contributes to the development of many central nervous system (CNS) pathologies. There is one type of waste called Amyloid-beta, a protein that is made in the brain all the time. Amyloid-beta is a key histopathological hallmark of Alzheimer’s disease. It builds up and aggregates in the spaces between the brain’s cells, instead of being cleared away like it’s supposed to be, when normal CSF circulation is disrupted (Simon & Iliff, 2016). By measuring, the clearance of amyloid-beta is much more rapid from the sleeping brain.

In other words, metabolic waste clearance is primarily a feature of the sleeping brain, rather than waking brain (Boespflug & Iliff, 2018). And, the many CNS pathologies, including neurodegenerative diseases (Alzheimer’s disease & Parkinson’s disease) are related to derangement of normal CSF circulation.

References:

Boespflug, E. L., & Iliff, J. J. (2018). The emerging relationship between interstitial Fluid–Cerebrospinal fluid exchange, amyloid-β, and sleep. Biological Psychiatry (1969), 83(4), 328-336. doi:10.1016/j.biopsych.2017.11.031

Fultz, N. E., Bonmassar, G., Setsompop, K., Stickgold, R. A., Rosen, B. R., Polimeni, J. R., & Lewis, L. D. (2019). Coupled electrophysiological, hemodynamic, and cerebrospinal fluid oscillations in human sleep. Science (American Association for the Advancement of Science), 366(6465), 628-631. doi:10.1126/science.aax5440

Iliff, J. (2014). One more reason to get a good night’s sleep. Retrieved July 21, 2020, from https://www.ted.com/talks/jeff_iliff_one_more_reason_to_get_a_good_night_s_sleep/transcript?language=en

Simon, M. J., & Iliff, J. J. (2016). Regulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) flow in neurodegenerative, neurovascular and neuroinflammatory disease. Biochimica Et Biophysica Acta. Molecular Basis of Disease, 1862(3), 442-451. doi:10.1016/j.bbadis.2015.10.014

William C. Shiel Jr., M. (2018, December 27). Definition of Cerebrospinal fluid. Retrieved July 21, 2020, from https://www.medicinenet.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=7529

[NIHNINDS]. (20) Brain Opens Up The Pipes During Sleep [Video]. YouTube. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=awAK_AkouYM&feature=emb_logo

typeData.textContent:
Stimulants are a type of drug that speed up neural activity in the body. By doing so, it could cause a person to feel more alert, awake, confident, or energetic. Over stimulation can be caused by ingesting large amounts of stimulants, and can cause symptoms such as anxiety, headaches and seizures.

Coffee is the most popular stimulant, as many people intake it as a source of caffeine on a daily basis. Illicit stimulant drugs include cocaine, amphetamine, meth, and crack. However, prescription stimulants include Ritalin, Adderall, Concerta, Dexedrine, and Vyvanse.


SYMPTOMS OF STIMULANTS:

Euphoria
Increased confidence
Reduced appetite
Mood swings
Dehydration
Anxiety
Sexual arousal
SHORT TERM EFFECTS

The short term effects include fatigue, depression, and insensitivity. After the stimulant wears off, these short term effects leads the stimulant user to want to use the drug again. However, the person is only using the stimulant to feel well again, without the effects.

LONG TERM EFFECTS

The long term effects can lead to feelings of paranoia or aggression as stimulants are highly addictive. They can also lead to high body temperature or irregular heartbeat.

TREATMENT FOR ABUSE AND ADDICTION

The first step to recovery is medical detox for those suffering long term abuse, where they are monitored around the clock, in an environment where doctors can come quickly if complications arise.

Comprehensive therapy is followed after, such as Cognitive Behavioural Therapy (CBT). Other mechanisms include:

Contingency Management: a form of therapy that involves giving clients rewards for participation, and useful for treating stimulant addiction.

The Matrix Model: is commonly used to address stimulant addiction. In this form of therapy, the therapist work to encourage positive behaviour within clients and help them gain self confidence and worth.

Works Cited 
“Stimulant Drug Types, Effects & Addiction Signs.” American Addiction Centers, 13 June 2019, americanaddictioncenters.org/stimulant-drugs.
“What Are Stimulants? List of Stimulant Drugs & Their Side Effects - Drug-Free World.” Foundation for a Drug-Free World, 2006, www.drugfreeworld.org/drugfacts/prescription/stimulants.html.
“Stimulants.” Stimulants - Alcohol and Drug Foundation, 2020, adf.org.au/drug-facts/stimulants/.

nodes.title: The Different Types of Opioids (Fallon Furkalo)
nodes.description: Description of opioids and the different drugs in the category.

typeData.textContent:
Opioids are a category of drugs that are naturally found in the opium poppy plant, some of them are made directly from the plant while others are manufactured in a lab by scientists using the same chemical structure. Opioids contain chemicals that relax the body and relieve pain (analgesic properties), this means they are often used as medicines. However, opioids can also be used recreationally by individuals looking for a high. Opioids are highly addictive, and overdoses and death are common. Heroin, morphine, methadone, codeine, fentanyl, and oxycodone are all opioids. 

Heroin is an illegal substance made from morphine in the opium poppy and has twice the potency of morphine. Heroin often contains additives (sugar, starch, or powdered milk) that can clog blood vessels that lead to the lungs, liver, kidneys, or brain, which can cause permanent damage. Heroin is highly addictive and can lead to overdoses that result in death. When going through withdrawal from heroin and other opiates, it is important to do so under the observation of a medical specialist as withdrawal can be lethal under certain circumstances. 

Morphine is found directly in the opium poppy and is the most active substance in the poppy. This drug is used to relieve severe pain and is named after the Morpheus, the Greek god of dreams. Morphine induces a feeling of euphoria described as a dreamlike state, thus the name. It is highly addictive, and tolerance to it can develop rather quickly. Morphine is also abused often due to its pleasurable effects and easy accessibility. 

Codeine is a man-made less powerful opioid than morphine. It is mostly used as a cough remedy and to treat minor pain. Codeine can be found over the counter in many countries around the world. Although codeine is less potent, it does have a potential for abuse. 

Fentanyl is a very powerful synthetic opioid that is quite similar to morphine but 50-100 times more potent. Fentanyl is a prescription drug used to treat severe pain and given to patients with chronic pain who are tolerant to other opioids. It is also made and used illegally, and is often mixed with other drugs (takes very little fentanyl to produce a high) leading to a very high rate of overdose deaths. 

Oxycodone is made in a lab by modifying thebaine (an organic chemical found in opium) and is a powerful painkiller. It is one of the most commonly abused prescription drugs and is very easy to become addicted to. Oxycodone addictions are very expensive, and an overdose from this drug can be deadly. 

Methadone was created in a German lab by scientists trying to find a painkiller for surgery use that was less addictive than heroin and morphine. However, methadone is believed to be more addicting than heroin. Unlike other opioids, methadone blocks the high from other opioids such as codeine, heroin, morphine, and oxycodone, which is why it is part of the treatment plan for opioid addiction.

nodes.title: Common tools for psychophysiological study of sleep (Conor Kent)

typeData.textContent:
With sleep being an essential part of our days, it is important that we have tools to monitor and teach us more about this fascinating process. There are three common tools used to monitor sleep:

1. Electroencephalogram (EEG): measures electrical activity of scalp. This is indicative of electrical activity in cortex and other structures.

The EEG can record the various sleep stages we go through by producing a graph. For example, when we are laying in bed with out eyes awake, the line is flat. Yet, once we shut our eyes and prepare ourselves mentally for sleep, alpha waves (brief bursts of 8-12 Hz EEG waves) appear. This would be a sign of hypnagogia (hypnagogic hallucinations), such as a voice or knock on the door.

2. Electrooculogram (EOG): measures eye activity. This is useful for seeing if we are in REM (rolling eye movement) sleep. Certain eye movements are indications of what stage of sleep we are in.

3. Electromyogram (EMG): measures muscle tension.

nodes.title: Sleep Deprivation Fill in the Blank (Kathy Duong)

typeData.textContent:
Throughout modern history, many theories have been posed for why we dream.  A Harvard psychiatrist, John Hobson, proposed the activation synthesis hypothesis in 1977.  His hypothesis was based on the observation that the brainstem sends random neural signals to the cerebral cortex during REM sleep.  Hobson believed that dreaming is the cortex trying to interpret and fill in the gaps of the random neural signals being sent to the brain.  Other theories have suggested that the dreamer’s subconscious mind attempts to string together memories into a narrative.  Later on in his career, Hobson added to his hypothesis by stating that dreaming is a simulation 
that is meant to prepare and predict the dreamer for waking life.
Many other theorists hypothesized why we dream.  The neuroscientist Sigmund Freud saw dreams as an opportunity to unlock the contents of the unconscious mind.  He also categorized dreams into two types of content: 1. Manifest content-the storyline.  2. Latent content-hidden meaning.  Similar to Freud, the psychiatrist Carl Jung believed that dreams allow oneself access to a stream of unconsciousness referred to as the collective unconscious.  Lastly, the researcher Rosalind Cartwright posed a theory of why dream: Dreams simply reflect events that seem to have great importance to the dreamer.  We only have theories and correlations for why we dream, more research may reveal empirical evidence for answering the intriguing question: Why do we dream?

Lucid dreaming is an incredibly intriguing concept. It is being aware that we are dreaming and is the ability to control its content. This phenomena, while deeply glorified in today’s pop culture, lacks credible scientific backing. Many psychologists have endeavored to study the nooks and crannies of Lucid dreaming, however, results have been limited so far. Researchers claim to use an EEG (electroencephalographic) machine which records the brain’s activity (electrical signals) through the electrodes placed on the scalp. Through this process, scientists can monitor the different stages of sleep, like REM sleep- the most common time to experience dreams. 

A multitude of benefits can be acquired through lucid dreaming. From a decrease in nightmares, to an increase motor skills, to an enhancement of creativity. On the other hand, lucid dreaming is not ideal for people with sleeping problems, depression and anxiety, dissociation and derealization. Additionally, vital research depicts the potential for understanding dreams better through delving further into research about lucid dreaming. Our bodies are paralyzed during sleep, however, we have control over the movement of our eyes, which is what indicates the researcher that the person is now in REM sleep (Rapid Eye Movement). With the use of the EEG machine, significant research has been pushed into the highlights regarding knowledge on dreams.

However, research conducted by Lacaux et al studied the link between lucid dreaming and creativity with participants who with narcolepsy. Lucid dreaming is a symptom of narcolepsy, hence upon studying that, this scientist discovered that lucid dreaming was associated with high creativity scores. The results also presented a strong correlation between REM sleep and dreaming to enhance creativity. Furthermore, another study conducted by students at Randolph-Macon College explored the relationship between creativity and lucid dreaming. The findings did not portray a relationship between the two. Nevertheless, the study shed light on the scope of research for examining other cognitive traits and functions that could help in the ability to lucid dream. 

Another added benefit is the relieving of anxiety induced by nightmares, especially for people who suffer through PTSD. This is because through lucid dreaming you are aware that it is a nightmare and it is not real. Even spiritual growth is an aspect touched upon by lucid dreaming. one can meditate in their dreams and in turn dwell on inner peace and gain access to a high level of self-awareness. However, it is important to comprehend that these claims are loosely tied with real evidence and can be purely coincidental and personal to those who described them. The generalizability of research in lucid dreaming is tremendously low. 

In conclusion, dreams are merely anecdotal and do not necessarily have categoric implications. Dreams is a widespread platform catering to many researchers’ works yet does not have a lot of concrete stance with respects to scientific explanations. While multiple factors dictate an enhancement of creativity due to lucid dreaming, there is a lot of controlled and additional information that will be needed to support that claim.

In this week’s class we looked at the topic of lucid dreaming for a brief stretch but did not quite get the chance to explore the topic. Lucid dreaming is when people are conscious that they are dreaming. It is a term of sleep during which we are able to control our thoughts and emotions whilst the dream is happening. People become aware of their surrounding environment while they lucid dream. They even become mindful of the fact that they are dreaming.
During REM sleep, our brain is very active. The heart rate and movement of eyes increase and it is during this period of sleep that people experience lucid dreaming. There is extensive interest in this experience since many believe that lucid dreaming enhances the creativity of a person. Though not scientifically proven, typically people who are more creative are able to lucid dream since they have heightened abilities to recall dreams and visualise events.   Apart from possibly sharpening a person’s creativity, lucid dreaming is also beneficial for anxiety management. It helps in decreasing recurring nightmares which may interfere with the quality of sleep. This helps in controlling stress, anxiety and PTSD (Post Traumatic Stress Disorder).   Increased levels of lucid dreaming helps people improve their motor skills too. Visualising physical movement while we dream activates the sensorimotor cortex which in turn helps with physical rehabilitation and athletic performance. 
Whilst lucid dreaming often happens randomly, it is possible to initiate it by using certain induction techniques. The wake back to bed (WBTB) method says that we should wake up five hours after sleeping and then stay awake for half an hour. After doing so, when we go back to sleep, the likelihood of entering REM sleep whilst conscious would increase thus growing the possibility of a lucid dream. Another popular induction technique is the mnemonic induction of lucid dreams (MILD) which is based on prospective memory. When we set an intention of doing something later, we are more likely to do it. Hence, if we keep reminding ourselves that we want to lucid dream, we will be more likely to do it.  
When we start lucid dreaming randomly the chances of any dangers are minimum. However, using induction techniques can be threatening. The WBTB and MILD techniques involve waking up in the middle of the night. They can thus cause sleep problems. Sleep disturbances can also lead to the feeling that people or the environment surrounding us are not real (derealisation).  More severe complications such as depression and sleep paralysis may also happen while using these techniques. 
Lucid dreams have been a popular research topic for decades. Its effect on the brain has been studied in the scientific community extensively especially due to its correlation with developing creativity. However, since there is no conclusive study yet proving whether this experience does actually enhance our creativity, it is important to continue research till we get an irrefutable opinion regarding its significance.  
References

1)“How To Lucid Dream: 5 Techniques, Benefits, and Cautions.” Accessed July 28, 2020. https://www.healthline.com/health/healthy-sleep/how-to-lucid-dream.

2)Healthline. “Lucid Dreams: What They Are and How to Experience Them,” June 17, 2019. https://www.healthline.com/health/what-is-lucid-dreaming.

nodes.title: How Opioids can become addictive explanation (Aaron Dokiburra)
nodes.description: Summary of how addictive opioids can be.

typeData.textContent:
Opioids are a class of drugs that are prescribed to treat severe pain.

•Examples of Opioids: Fentanyl, Heroin, Morphine, and Codeine to name a few common ones.

These drugs can become very addictive very quickly and individuals often find it hard to come off, nearly 80% of people who use heroin misused prescription opioids. (NIH, 2020)

What makes Opioids Addictive?

•What makes opioids more at risk for danger compared to other drugs? Opioids unlike a lot of other drugs can cross the blood-brain barrier (BBB) which is a selective semipermeable border that protects solutes from blood getting into the CNS.

Opioids can cross the BBB and change the chemistry of the brain as well as increase the drug’s tolerance. Resulting in the individual taking a higher dose to gain the same effect as the previous time. This snowball effect leads to addiction and over a long period of time turns into total dependence of the drug.

•Opioid addiction is very dangerous and life-threatening, it can often lead to overdose where an individual slows their breathing or breathing total stops.

Reference:
National Institute on Drug Abuse. (2020, June 10). Opioid Overdose Crisis. Retrieved July 29, 2020, from https://www.drugabuse.gov/drug-topics/opioids/opioid-overdose-crisis

typeData.textContent:
In week 10’s material, the textbook goes more into the topic of parasomnias and some of its examples. The book mentions “Sleepwalking, restless leg syndrome, and night terrors [as] all examples of parasomnias” (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000), however one particular examples the text misses out on is sleep paralysis

According to webMD, “Sleep paralysis is a feeling of being conscious but unable to move. It occurs when a person passes between stages of wakefulness and sleep.” Its symptoms range widely, from having a feeling of flying around, leaving one's own body, being unable to breath or move, and even the feeling of being suffocated. 

One notable symptom that sleep paralysis has is hallucination. Reported by those who have sleep paralysis, some types of hallucinations are common, and actually appear similarly in different individual’s experience. These hallucinations can vary from seeing an old lady next to your bed, a tall, shadowy figure with a cloak or hat standing in the corner, and even shadows of small children moving about. These hallucinations can accompany the symptoms of feeling like you're suffocating and/or being unable to move.

Before psychology and the detailed studies of the brain and sleep, in the past these hallucinations were believed to be spirits.

Different Theories for Why We Sleep (Jack Pitcher)
nodes.description: A short essay describing various theories for why we need sleep, drawing on the Harvard Medical School article found here (http://healthysleep.med.harvard.edu/healthy/matters/benefits-of-sleep/why-do-we-sleep).

typeData.textContent:
Every single person on earth is familiar with sleep, yet no one can explain exactly why we need it. At first, it may seem intuitive to sleep - thinking from a Darwinian perspective, if there evolved a mutation in humans that allowed them to survive with no sleep, surely these humans would have been preferred over us sleep-needing people. Just imagine how much you could get done if you never had to sleep! You could work full time and take six classes at school no problem. Yet we are stuck with sleep, so clearly there is some basic reason we need to sleep, just like we need to eat and drink. In this short essay, I draw on the ideas written in a Harvard Medical School article called “Why Do We Sleep?” in order to synthesize the various theories and determine that it is the brain that really needs sleep, and that this idea will propel new research in many different directions.

The first theory mentioned in “Why Do We Sleep?” is that sleep helped protect us and conserved energy when humans were at their weakest. Before the discovery of fire, nighttime meant that humans were effectively blind, so it makes sense that we should sleep away the night, reducing our bodies energy requirements and stopping us from exploring the wrong places. However, this cannot be the full picture, since humans could have simply evolved night vision or some other method of seeing in the dark, like plenty of other animals have, which would have been much more efficient than sleep. So, while perhaps this was an additional benefit, there must be a different driving benefit to sleep.

Another idea is that sleep helps to restore our bodies’ functions. A good example of this is muscle growth. Your muscles only grow when you’re sleeping, so after you workout it’s important to get a good night’s rest; otherwise, all the “gains” you worked hard for will go to waste. However, perhaps even more interesting is that the brain also requires sleep. The brain seems to learn more while asleep, and it seems to use sleep in order to adapt to new information that has been learned throughout the day. It is not uncommon to go to sleep trying to figure out a problem, and upon waking up to have the solution pop into your head. Another evidence that the brain needs sleep is that, according to the Harvard Medical School, it produces adenosine, a byproduct of neuronal activity, while we are awake, and this build up of adenosine could be what makes us feel tired. When we sleep, our brains have a chance to clear out all the adenosine so we wake up feeling refreshed.

The idea that the human brain requires sleep to function has fascinating implications for many different fields of research, from cognitive neuroscience to artificial intelligence and beyond. If the human brain needs sleep and our computers do not need to sleep, perhaps there is some missing link that is missing, and this missing link could explain the difference in the ways humans and computers think. No matter what the answer is, the real reason why we sleep is still an active area of research, and one that will remain an interesting subject for discussion for a long time.

References:
Why Do We Sleep, Anyway? (2007). Retrieved August 01, 2020, from http://healthysleep.med.harvard.edu/healthy/matters/benefits-of-sleep/why-do-we-sleep

nodes.title: What happens when we don't get enough sleep? (Nathan Bears)
nodes.description: Medical experts recommend we get at least 8 hours of sleep per night. What happens when we don't?

typeData.textContent:
Medical experts recommend you get between 8 and 10 hours of sleep per night. But for some people, 6 hours is enough, and for others, they need up to 12 hours. The amount of sleep that a person needs is dependent on the person's lifestyle, as well as their genetics. Sleep is a restorative function, so losing sleep is detrimental to our everyday bodily functions, as well as our mental and cognitive functioning.

When a person doesn't get enough sleep at night, they start to build up what is known as a "sleep debt". A sleep debt is basically what is sounds like, you lose more and more sleep until the effects of the lack of sleep start to accumulate. The short term effects include fatigue, daytime sleepiness, and irritability, and the long term effects include high blood pressure, increased risk for diabetes, and obesity.

nodes.title: What is a Healthy Amount of Sleep Per Night? (Nathan Bears)
How much sleep do we need each night? (Nathan Bears)
nodes.description: What happens when we don't get enough sleep?

typeData.textContent:
Medical experts recommend we get between 8 and 10 hours per night. for some people only 6 hours are sufficient, and for others they need to sleep 12 hours to feel well rested. But what happens when we don't get enough sleep? what effect does a lack of sleep have on the body? Sleep is something we all need, and often is something we don't get enough of, so don't take sleep for granted. If you do, you could see some negative health consequences as a result.

When a person doesn't get enough sleep at night, they start to experience something called "Sleep Debt". Sleep debt is basically the accumulation of lost hours of sleep, which have an adverse effect on your body, as well as your cognitive functions. The short term effects of sleep debt include fatigue, irritability, and daytime sleepiness, while the long term effects include high blood pressure, and an increased risk of diabetes and obesity.

According to Harvard Health Publishing, when a person accrues sleep debt, they can't get that sleep back, even by trying to sleep in on the weekend in order to catch up. In fact, those who cut sleep during the week, but increased their sleep on the weekends still paid a cast. These costs include increased calorie intake, reduced energy expenditure, increased weight, and even changes to how the body uses insulin. Additionally, staying up later and sleeping later on the weekends might further complicate things by basically jet-lagging the body's internal clock, which can throw our internal systems out of whack and disrupt many of the body's internal functions.

The amount of sleep we get each night affects us on a daily basis. If we miss sleep, there is no getting it back, that much has been made clear. If you stick to a schedule and get to sleep on time, you'll be feeling fine the next morning, but if not, there's no recovery unless you restart your schedule. Take your sleep seriously, its pretty important.

Article cited:

https://www.health.harvard.edu/blog/weekend-catch-up-sleep-wont-fix-the-effects-of-sleep-deprivation-on-your-waistline-2019092417861

nodes.title: Information on stimulants (Hannah Koroll)
nodes.description: This node further investigates the dangers, effects, and general information about some of the most common stimulant drugs.

typeData.textContent:
There are many different types of drugs that people can take either medicinally or recreationally. The three (four with antipsychotics) main categories that we can group drugs into include “depressants”, “hallucinogens”, and “stimulants” which is the one I will be discussing today. There are numerous drugs that fit into these categories and not without overlap. My other group members, Chloe is delving into the hallucinogens deeper, and Hannah W will explore the depressants. As I alluded to earlier, there is overlap between categories; Nicotine, Marijuana, MDMA, Mescaline, LSD, Psilocybin, and AMT are all stimulants that also possess qualities of either depressants or hallucinogens (or both in the case of marijuana), demonstrating that categories are not mutually exclusive. 
	Now that I’ve introduced some drugs that have numerous labels I’d like to transition into the drugs that are exclusively stimulants. Amphetamines, Khat, Ritalin, and Cocaine are all labeled ‘psychomotor stimulants’ and Caffeine, Theophylline, and Theobromine are all ‘methylxanthines’. These stimulants increase neural activity and “act as agonists of the dopamine neurotransmitter system” meaning that it will accelerate activity of neurotransmitter system, whereas antagonists block neural activity. Cocaine, amphetamines, ecstasy, caffeine, nicotine, and cathinones are all stimulants that have abuse potential due to being agonists of dopamine which is associated with reward and craving. Cocaine, for example, blocks the reuptake of dopamine in the neural synapse that occurs, hence agonizing it and creating that potentially addictive high. This drug is commonly used recreationally due to the extreme happiness and energy users experience as well as the apparent ease to obtain it on the streets. Additionally, cocaine as a street drug is very dangerous due to not only the direct side effects of the drug, but also the chance of it being mixed with other drugs such as amphetamine or synthetic opioids such as fentanyl which can be very lethal and has caused an increase in the number of cocaine overdoses. 
	Amphetamines also works by blocking dopamine reuptake. Methamphetamine, an type of amphetamine, is a rather accessible drug due to being able to make at home from common ingredients, in addition to being inexpensive, can help explain why it had become increasingly widespread.
	The most commonly used drug is caffeine, which makes sense due to much of the world enjoying a cup of coffee in the morning. Luckily, caffeine is not nearly as dangerous as other drugs in the stimulant category (or any category for that matter), as no one has ever died of caffeine, although there has been one reported case of a rather unhealthy dependence to the drug, but this is extremely rare. Caffeine causes high blood levels which can cause insomnia, agitation, muscle twitching, nausea, irregular heartbeat and (unlikely) death; it also gives positive effects such as raised alertness and arousal. 

https://www.drugabuse.gov/publications/drugfacts/cocaine

nodes.title: Parasomnia: Sleep paralysis (Coby Zamoranos)
nodes.description: A deeper look into a form of parasomnia

typeData.textContent:
In week 10’s material, the textbook goes more into the topic of parasomnias and some of its examples. The book mentions “Sleepwalking, restless leg syndrome, and night terrors [as] all examples of parasomnias” (Mahowald & Schenck, 2000), however one particular examples the text misses out on is sleep paralysis

According to webMD, “Sleep paralysis is a feeling of being conscious but unable to move. It occurs when a person passes between stages of wakefulness and sleep.” Its symptoms range widely, from having a feeling of flying around, leaving one's own body, being unable to breath or move, and even the feeling of being suffocated. 

One notable symptom that sleep paralysis has is hallucination. Reported by those who have sleep paralysis, some types of hallucinations are common, and actually appear similarly in different individual’s experience. These hallucinations can vary from seeing an old lady next to your bed, a tall, shadowy figure with a cloak or hat standing in the corner, and even shadows of small children moving about. These hallucinations can accompany the symptoms of feeling like you're suffocating and/or being unable to move.

Before psychology and the detailed studies of the brain and sleep, in the past these hallucinations were believed to be spirits. 

http://sleepeducation.org/sleep-disorders-by-category/parasomnias
https://amhsnewspaper.com/20331/mythical-monsters/mythical-monsters-sleep-paralysis-figures/

https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/sleep-paralysis#:~:text=Sleep%20paralysis%20is%20a%20feeling,or%20a%20sense%20of%20choking.

What Are Dreams?
Dreams occur during REM sleep, which is characterized by one's awake-like brain activity and rapid eye movements. They are made up of the dreamer's experiences, emotions, and ideas that are combined to create a unique storyline during sleep. Though they happen involuntarily, one can control the contents of their dreams via lucid dreaming. There are many plausible theories behind why we have dreams. Freud and Jung thought that dreams allowed access to our unconcious minds. Cartwright's theory proposed that dreams are reflection of important lifetime events that are organized by the brain in a sensible manner. On the contrary, Hobson believed that dreams are virtual simulations that prepare us for similar situations in the future. 

What Are Illusions?
Illusions are misinterpretations of visual stimuli while one is awake. A famous example of an illusion is the Müller-Lyer illusion where the viewer's perception of two identical lines is distorted when placed in front of a visually confusing background. The viewer must be shown the visual stimuli, in this case, the picture, for the illusion to take place.

What Are Sleep Hallucinations?
Sleep hallucinations are altered sensory perceptions that causes one to imagine something that is not real. They occur between the stage of waking and sleeping as opposed to in the stages themselves, like dreams. Sleep hallucinations can be caused by the intake of drugs such as MDMA and LSD, as well as many stress-related factors. There are two types of hallucinations: hypnagogic and hypnopompic. Hypnagogic hallucinations occur right before falling sleep, while hypnopompic hallucinations occur right after sleep upon awakening. Both distort the subject's reality and may be accompanied by sleep paralysis. Though there is no direct treatment for sleep hallucinations, many patients seek help from sleep specialists and therapists to help control their frequencies.

Source: https://www.sleepassociation.org/sleep-disorders/more-sleep-disorders/hallucinations-during-sleep/

nodes.title: REM dreams and NREM dreams (Charles Zhu)
Quiz on REM dreams and NREM dreams (Charles Zhu)

typeData.textContent:
We individuals always wonder how much sleep to get. Five hours of sleep or 15 hours of sleep and one still feels foggy and un alert. So, what is the answer to sleep and how much is too little or too less. Well, all the way back in 1964 a man by the name of Randy Gardner did not sleep for over eleven days (264 hours to be exact). Now, the question is was that okay to do? Can we all do this?
	Randy Gardner started his journey and right away on the first day of no sleep said he felt foggy and nauseous. Then his body had gotten used to it and going days without sleep was not an issue. However, this was not the case for his mind. Randy reported feeling dizzy with a lack of memory. He even states “I mean, it was crazy, where you couldn't remember things, it was almost like an early Alzheimer's thing brought on by lack of sleep.” This is his first and pretty much last negative comment about being sleep deprived. Being awake for 264 hours did not have any ill effects on him and even when Randy first went to sleep after his sleepless marathon, he claims to have woken up fine. For his first sleep in over eleven days, researchers took Randy in and attached him to an EEG machine to monitor his sleep. He slept for fourteen hours and reported feeling back to normal again. Even when asked if it was difficult to get in a sleep routine again he said “No, not at all. I went right back to the regular mode. Everything was fine. Strange, isn't it?” Randy Gardner is now 71 years young and does not like to miss out on a single hour of his sleep. He highly recommends getting a full night's rest. Therefore, to answer our question; although it appears reducing sleep has no side effects, it is highly recommended to get a full night's sleep. Humans all have the right and need for three things; food, water, and good old sleep. 

Vedantam, S. (2017, December 27). The Haunting Effects Of Going Days Without Sleep. Retrieved August 04, 2020, from https://www.npr.org/2017/12/27/573739653/the-haunting-effects-of-going-days-without-sleep

nodes.title: Can Meditation or Hypnosis Replace Lost Sleep? (Carmen Mah)
The Science Behind Post-traumatic Nightmares (Carol Kamel)

typeData.textContent: Nightmares are a disease that plague us all, their timing and terrifying nature produce images that are remembered. But where do they originate from and what aspects of our lives contribute and perpetuate them? According to Harvard Medical School, nightmares arise for a variety of reasons. Some of which include: anxiety, stress, medication, and irregular sleep. However, nightmares arise most consistently in those who have been diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder. This specific faction of nightmares are termed "post-traumatic nightmares." These nightmares involve the amygdala, a region deep in the brain. The amygdala is best known for its crucial role in the processing of fear, threats, and danger. This part of the brain is deeply sensitive and therefore amplifies the nightmares. Moreover, the fraction of those whose wellbeing is deeply affected by nightmares can seek treatment in a number of ways. For instance, psychological therapy specifically for nightmares is called image rehearsal therapy (IRT). This therapy entails recalling and recording the content of the nightmare, then the individual is asked to rewrite the nightmare with a positive ending. The individual rehearses the rewritten/positive version before bed with the aim of removing the unwanted content during sleep. Additionally, the "American Journal of Psychiatry" published a study in which they deemed that the drug prazosin could be effective in relieving nightmares in those with PTSD. The drug is typically used to relieve hypertension, but combats PTSD by reducing the level of the neurochemicals in pathways that become overstimulated in PTSD.

nodes.title: Lactuca virosa: the wild lettuce plant [Brainz - Caitlin]

typeData.textContent:
The wild lettuce (Lactuca virosa) plant is a leafy green sprout with purple stems that is primarily found in Europe, the Middle East and North America. While the leaf of the plant is rarely used in medicinal settings, the sap secreted in the stem is dried into a resin, which is then smoked to relieve pain, aid in sleep and and to induce lucid dreaming. Although smoking is the most common form of ingestion, it could also be mixed into fruit smoothies or made into tea before bed. Within a short period of time, it gives similar effects as opium due to large quantities of lactucopicrin and lactucin present.

Wild lettuce extract was used in medicine as early as the 12th century and was widely noted for its psychoactive and sedative characteristics when ingested. The indigenous Hopi tribe used wild lettuce as a way to enter lucid dreaming states that give more information about reality than normal REM dreaming states.

typeData.textContent:
Drugs are mind-altering substances. In particular, stimulants are drugs that heighten neural activity by increasing the number of dopamine neurotransmitters in the brain. By doing so, the user’s alertness is drastically increased. Stimulants can be effective treatments for certain psychological disorders, however, as they are highly addictive, abuse of the drug may occur. Some people may even choose to take stimulants for recreational purposes. Cocaine, amphetamines, cathinones, MDMA, nicotine, and caffeine are all stimulant drugs. The first four all provide a “euphoric high” upon intake into the human body, but they are accompanied by strong side effects. Side effects include nausea and increased blood pressure and heart rate to the point the person experiences anxiety or psychosis is induced; thus, those drugs are deemed illicit. Psychotic episodes following the intake of the drug can be in the form of hallucinations or paranoia.


ILLICIT Drugs

Cocaine
-most often taking by snorting
-takes effect very fast
-an agonist of dopamine
-gives a “euphoric high”
-unregulated production
-come in the form of powder

Amphetamines
-can be used to treat Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) because they provide relaxing effects, in which case would make it a licit drug
-an agonist of dopamine
-come in the form of crystals

3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA)—also known as Ecstasy or Molly
-increases feelings of pleasure
-common at club or party scenes
-unregulated production
-come in the form of pills

Cathinones
-have similar effects to amphetamines
-unregulated production
-come in the form of bath salt crystals 


LICIT Drugs

Caffeine, most commonly found in coffee, and nicotine, found in cigarettes, are ubiquitous around us. Coffee and tea help people stay awake throughout the day because of their caffeine content. On the other hand, the addictive nature of nicotine makes smoking cigarettes a habit where the cons outweigh the pros.

nodes.title: Week 10: Fatal Familial Insomnia (Erin Cheng)
nodes.description: Fatal Sleeping Disorder: Dying to Sleep

typeData.textContent:
What is it: 
Fatal Familial Insomnia (FFI) is an extremely rare, genetically inherited neurodegenerative disease characterized by the inability to sleep. Initially, patients will experience mild insomnia that progressively worsens, leading to the complete inability to sleep and ultimately death. This particular disorder has a significant effect on the thalamus, a brain structure in charge of regulating important bodily functions such as sleep, body temperature and appetite. Therefore, patients with FFI usually develop symptoms associated with the deterioration of the thalamus such as dementia, panic attacks, weight loss, hallucinations and various motor issues. 

How is it caused: 
Fatal Familial Insomnia is a prion disease, a family of conditions that result in a loss of neurons. FFI is caused by a mutation in the PRPN gene, resulting in misfolded prion proteins that build up in the thalamus, causing it to lose neurons progressively. Usually, prion diseases are passed down genetically, however, some individuals developed fatal insomnia without any genetic factors. This form of fatal insomnia is known as Sporadic Fatal Insomnia (SFI), a non-genetic form of FFI caused without a variation in the PRNP gene. Currently, the underlying cause of SFI is still unknown and scientists are continuing to research this disease.

Treatment: 
As of now, there is no cure for FFI, however there is treatment to manage symptoms specific to each patient. Treatment methods require the input of many healthcare workers including psychiatrists, neurologists, and pain specialists. Some additional symptomatic treatment includes anti-seizure medications and the cessation of medication that may cause confusion and affect memory. 

References: 

(n.d.). Fatal Familial Insomnia - NORD (National Organization for .... Retrieved August 5, 2020, from https://rarediseases.org/rare-diseases/fatal-familial-insomnia/

nodes.title: Cocaine and the War on Drugs (Madeleine DesBrisay)

typeData.textContent:
In the 1980s, panic swept across America as reports of a new, highly addictive drug emerged -- crack cocaine. Several key misconceptions about crack led to harsher sentences for crack involved offenses which disproportionately affected minority communities and led to lasting effects. 

Cocaine is an example of a stimulant -- a drug that increases neural activity. Like many other stimulants, cocaine is an agonist of dopamine meaning that it increases dopamine’s effects. Cocaine affects the body’s natural reward system and is associated with addiction and craving. Cocaine can be found primarily in two forms. Crack is the base form of cocaine and is smoked rather than snorted or injected. Smoking the drug allows it to reach the brain faster. Although the effects of crack manifest in the body more quickly, crack and cocaine have extremely similar physiological effects.

Despite the similarities between crack and cocaine, in the 1980s, crack users were punished more severely than cocaine users for the same offences. For example possession of 500g of cocaine and 5 g of crack would both give mandatory minimum sentences of 5 years.

Since crack was cheaper and more easily accessible, poorer communities generally used crack whereas individuals in more affluent neighbourhoods tended to use powder cocaine. These laws disproportionately affected minority communities. 

While legislators argued that crack was more addictive than cocaine, this argument is not backed by the scientific community. A study published by the Journal of the American Medical Association revealed that crack cocaine is not significantly more addictive than powder cocaine. 

These laws affected the surge of the American prison population in recent decades -- the US now has the highest prison population in the world. It also profoundly affected minority communities, specifically African Americans. The effects of the “War on Drugs” are still being felt by minority communities today. 

References: 

5 Myths About That Demon Crack. (2007, October 14). Retrieved August 06, 2020, from https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/10/09/AR2007100900751_2.html

Sleep and the lack of it on your brain- Jonathan Hao

typeData.textContent:
Sleep deprivation is an issue almost all of us deal with at some point in their lives , however the discussion of its effect on the brain is rarely discussed in full.Sleep is one of the most essential needs of a human being. Sleep being one of the most fundamental requirements according to Maslow's hierarchy of needs. Not only do we spend almost a third of our lives in this state , most organisms share in this aspect. However , what happens when we don't meet our daily quota of sleep is that it can lead to neurodegenerative diseases and psychiatric disorders.

The reason that sleep is a vital ,crucial part of the brain is that it is involved in much of its maintenance. With an example being the waste system via the glymphatic system , which works best when under the effects of sleep.Without this process , many proteins that are attributed to neurodegenerative diseases such as alzheimers.Sleep has also been seen to have connections to our prefrontal cortex and our brains reward and emotion-processing centers.Sleeping has also been known to remove toxins in your brain that build up during the day when you are awake.

However , sleep deprivation robs all of these benefits and more..Studies have also shown that our society as a whole is leaned towards sleep deprivation , as many of our job shifts are irregular and do not integrate well with the amount of recommended sleep.Which has been shown to be 7 to 9 hours.

Thus, sleep deprivation is a prevalent issue , and with proper research can result in the overall growth of our health as a race.Studying sleep deprivation can also lead to more in depth understanding of how the brain works and should be a sought after research topic.











References
https://dana.org/article/the-sleep-deprived-brain/
https://www.verywellmind.com/what-is-maslows-hierarchy-of-needs-4136760
https://www.ninds.nih.gov/Disorders/Patient-Caregiver-Education/Understanding-Sleep#:~:text=Sleep%20is%20important%20to%20a,up%20while%20you%20are%20awake.

nodes.title: What is LSD? What does tripping feel like? (Julie Lam)

typeData.textContent:
Lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), commonly known as acid, was discovered by a pharmaceutical researcher accidentally in the late 1930s.

Acid is produced from a fungus that grows mostly rye, and on other grains. It is often made in laboratories in countries where this is an illegal drug. The acid solution is then soaked into the absorbent paper, where it dries and is cut into small squares (known as tabs or hits). Acid can be taken injected, inhaled, and as a liquid. The process that you feel after consuming acid is called an acid trip.

What does tripping on acid feel like?

The effects of tripping on acid vary from person to person. Each experience will be different, however, most may experience sensationalized perceptions of their surroundings. These symptoms may begin to show after 20 to 90 minutes of taking an initial dose. Some examples may be "seeing" colours, "smelling" words or "tasting" sounds. Still objects may also begin to "move" or visually change. 

These changes and signs may lessen in intensity as the process of coming down begins. As acid is a long-acting drug, this process can be expected to start after several hours of tripping. 

The final stage of tripping is the afterglow. This is where things may feel "lighter" and "better" than before the trip. This can happen approximately a few hours after coming down. Flashbacks of the trip itself are also common.

nodes.title: REM Sleep and Memory Consolidation (Beth Patrick)
nodes.description: New Findings on REM Sleep and Memory Consolidation

typeData.textContent:
As cited in the OpenStax textbook, there is still disagreement among the science community about how important non-REM and REM sleep are for normal learning and memory (Siegel, 2001). While people often view sleep deprivation as a problem, REM deprivation can actually be less detrimental. In some cases, it can have positive consequences, such as for people who suffer from depression. As Dr. Barnes discussed, when considering the purpose of REM sleep, there is an issue with claiming that REM sleep is necessary for processing memories. Dr. Barnes stated that tricyclic antidepressant drugs (or other antidepressants) will block a patient's REM sleep, but the patient will not show a deficit in the processing of memories. More research needs to be completed to understand why sleep deprivation is helpful for some individuals, and harmful to others. 

Additionally, some scientists debate the claim that only REM sleep deprivation has positive consequences, and suggest that sleep deprivation in other stages is just as effective. Therefore, there needs to be more research as to how memories are processed during REM sleep and the other sleep stages.

One recent study by Kumar et al. at the University of Tsukuba, attempted to learn more about the types of neurons in the hippocampus that allow for memory consolidation during REM sleep. As defined by Byrne, memory consolidation is the process in which recent learned experiences are transformed into long-term memory, through structural and chemical changes in the brain such as synaptic connections between neurons (Byrne, 2008). The motivation of the University of Tsukuba study was to examine the role of adult-born neurons (ABNs) in memory consolidation during sleep, as the concept had never been previously studied. The only other study on young ABNs tested mice for 12 minutes at a time, which is not long enough to examine ABNs during sleep. In that study, there were inconclusive results about the increase or decrease of memory consolidation. 

The University of Tsukuba study monitored the EEG and EMG waves of mice in order to explore how the activity of young adult-born neurons (ABNs) in the dentate gyrus region in the hippocampus affect memory consolidation during REM sleep, as mice display a mammalian dentate gyrus region similar to that of humans. Researchers tested the activity of ABNs in the dentate gyrus region by silencing ABNs during REM sleep with optogenetic silencing. Memory consolidation was tested with fear memory, by monitoring the mice’s shock response. Scientists were interested in studying young adult-born neurons in the dentate gyrus region of the hippocampus because, while their activity is sparse, ABNs demonstrate a higher level of plasticity in that region, making it likely that they play a role in memory consolidation (Kumar et al., 2020). 

The study provided causal evidence that activity in young adult-born neurons during REM sleep is necessary for memory consolidation. The study was able to make the conclusion of a causal effect because silencing young ABN activity during REM sleep within the memory consolidation window impaired memory, whereas silencing outside the memory consolidation window (i.e., >6 h after fear conditioning) had no such effect (Kumar et al., 2020). Furthermore, no memory impairment was observed when immature (2-week-old) ABNs were silenced in REM sleep, or when fully mature (10-week-old) ABNs were silenced. 

The researchers clarified by stating, “specific ABNs encounter synaptic changes that enable memory consolidation, and these synaptic changes may depend on synchronization between specific ABNs and brain oscillations that take place during REM sleep” (Kumar et al., 2020). Hopefully, there will continue to be more research on REM sleep and memory consolidation. Further research on the role of young adult-born neurons during REM sleep could contribute to a better understanding of how memories are “formed, retrieved and consolidated” (Kumar et al., 2020).

References
Byrne, J. H. (2017). Learning and memory: A comprehensive reference (Second ed.). GB:  Academic Press.

Kumar, D., Koyanagi, I., Carrier-Ruiz, A., Vergara, P., Srinivasan, S., Sugaya, Y., . . . Sakaguchi, M. 
(2020). Sparse activity of hippocampal adult-born neurons during REM sleep is necessary for memory consolidation. Neuron (Cambridge, Mass.), doi:10.1016/j.neuron.2020.05.008

OpenStax College. Psychology. OpenStax CNX. Oct 31, 2018.

Use of Stimulants in Sports (Amir Hosseini)

typeData.textContent:
Introduction 

           Stimulants are chemicals used to increase neural activity and to enhance physical and cognitive performance. Stimulants can increase alertness, metabolic concentration, metabolic rate, power, strength, and decrease fatigue.  Several examples of stimulants are cocaine, amphetamines, cathinone, MDMA, nicotine and caffeine. Professional and recreational athletes tend to use all kinds of stimulants to increase performance and to have an edge on others. The primary sources of stimulants for athletes are energy drinks and pre-workout supplements, which may consist of caffeine and MDEA. 

Side Effects 

           Several side effects come with the use of such stimulants, but the most common are an increase in blood pressure, heart attacks, chest pain, shortness of breath, stroke, palpitations, dizziness and anxiety. Additionally, it is crucial to recognize that many intermediate and professional events drug test athletes, since the use of certain stimulants are prohibited.

Summary

	Some stimulants are a great supplement to be used to enhance one’s performance. Yet, it is still essential to evaluate your needs and conditions with a doctor/professional to avoid the terrible side effects.

References

	OpenStax College (2014). Introduction to Psychology. OpenStax College. URL:https://openstax.org/books/psychology/pages/1-introduction

	Momaya, A., Fawal, M., & Estes, R. (2015). Performance-enhancing substances in sports: a review of the literature. Sports medicine (Auckland, N.Z.), 45(4), 517–531. https://doi.org/10.1007/s40279-015-0308-9

typeData.textContent:
Sleeping pills have become more popular over the years. In the United States, it was found that one in three adults aged 65-80 use over the counter sleeping aid products. Most commonly, diphenhydramine is often taken for allergies, but can also act as a sleeping aid to promote drowsiness. Other medicines such as Ambien act on the GABA receptors in the brain, slowing down its activity, decreasing its alertness and increasing relaxation. 

However, these sleeping aids come with risks and side effects. The use of diphenhydramine, such as Benadryl or Tylenol PM will inhibit the release of acetylcholine neurotransmitters, known to be important for muscle contraction and brain function. This can result in difficulty urinating, constipation, delirium, and unwanted sleepiness in the morning. Tolerance can also occur when used for over two weeks. 

On the other hand, medicine that acts on GABA receptors in the brain such as Ambien or Lunesta can also disruptions to an individual’s memory, behaviors before sleep, and can even cause hallucinations. Rarely, sleepwalking can occur after taking these drugs. 

Melatonin has also grown in popularity among young people. Though melatonin can help individuals fall asleep, there are a few caveats. Melatonin is especially sensitive with timing, and dosing can be complicated. Over usage can result in headaches, nausea, dizziness, irritability, or even drowsiness in the daytime. Not to mention, long term use can significantly disrupt your sleep cycle, causing long term problems. 

Altogether, there needs to be an increase in awareness of these side effects that exist with taking sleeping aids. Individuals should reach out to healthcare professionals to assess whether or not they truly need sleeping aids, or just need to make incremental lifestyle changes.

nodes.title: Medical Marijuana (Jose Navarro)
nodes.description: Short essay on the evidence surrounding medical marijuana

typeData.textContent:
Week 10: Medical Marijuana (Jose Navarro)
Cannabinoids as the principal molecules that interact with synapses, the most common of which is TCH (Tetrahydrocannabinol). Because of the similar shape of THC to endocannabinoids, THC binds to cannabinoid receptors in the brain which are associated with appetite, pleasure, and memory. This inhibits endocannabinoids from binding to those receptors suppressing normal neural function.

This image has an empty alt attribute; its file name is nUjeyQ6.png
THC may provide certain advantageous properties to the plants that produce it, such as absorbing UV rays and antibiotic properties. Significant benefits for medicinal use have been seen not only for these properties; trials in patients undergoing chemotherapy show it reduces nausea, improves appetite in AIDS patients, and as a form of pain relief and relaxant.


However, usage of marijuana does have adverse effects. THC is more potent than the brain's neurotransmitors which causes the "high" sensation--there is an impairment in cognitive function leading to a deficiency in planning and decision making. Long term effects of marijuana usage are inconclusive with some evidence suggesting some form of impairment while most metastudies concluding no significant difference between users and non-users. Ingestion through smoking in particular has the same adverse effects asociated with smoking other substances.

Despite the existance of evidence in favor of medical cannabis, and little to no evidence showing adverse effectts, the United States classifies it as a Schedule I drug : "substances, or chemicals are defined as drugs with no currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse." However, its benefits are recognized at state level, with some states fully legalizing its use for both medical and recreational purpouses.

Bibliography
Green, H. (2020, August 6). How Weed Works: THC. Retrieved from Youtube: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FsJzCdFlpyQ

National Institute on Drug Abuse. (2020, August 6). How does marijuana produce its effects? Retrieved from Drugabuse: https://www.drugabuse.gov/publications/research-reports/marijuana/how-does-marijuana-produce-its-effects

Penny F. Whiting, P., Robert F. Wolff, M., & Sohan Deshpande, M. (2015). Cannabinoids for Medical Use A Systematic Review and Meta-analysis. JAMA.

US Governemnt. (2020, August 6). Drug Scheduling. Retrieved from DEA: https://www.dea.gov/drug-scheduling

nodes.title: A Brief Look at the Molecular Basis of Drug Tolerance (Tyrone Ly)
nodes.description: A Brief Look at the Molecular Basis of Drug Tolerance

typeData.textContent:
In this week’s lecture, we have been introduced to the concept of drug tolerance and perhaps some of its general mechanisms. Metabolic tolerance is the result of changes that reduce the amount of a drug getting to its site of action, and functional tolerance occurs when exposure to a drug causes a decrease in reactivity of its site of action. But, have you ever wondered how all of these processes happen at the molecular level?
        Let’s use alcohol as our example. When interacting with a particular type of ion protein channels – called BK channels – on the neuronal plasma membrane, alcohol can increase their opening probability, which leads to activation and allows the flow of ions (Pietrzykowski & Treistman, 2008). Moreover, membrane lipids are also essential in regulating how these proteins respond to alcohol, whereas BK channels embedded in thin lipid bilayers will be more easily potentiated by alcohol. With a higher membrane thickness, accompanied by an increase in cholesterol content, alcohol activity can be effectively inhibited (Pietrzykowski & Treistman, 2008). However, exposure to the substance can also cause changes to the membrane composition, specifically short exposures will decrease the amount of bound cholesterol and lead to a rise in membrane fluidity. Surprisingly, cholesterol content will eventually recover after long exposures as the membrane has now gained its tolerance, with a reduction in the channel sensitivity (Pietrzykowski & Treistman, 2008).
        Research has found that auxiliary proteins clustered with BK channels, known as β-subunits, can interact with the main subunits to prevent alcohol from potentiating the channel, indicating changes in subunit content will potentially result in tolerance development. Evidently, transcription and translation of certain membrane protein subunits, in addition to those of BK channels, are selectively altered by alcohol upon exposure (Pietrzykowski & Treistman, 2008). These modifications in fact contribute to the process of allostasis, which maintains stability in channel functions as a response to changes induced by the presence of alcohol and later on results in higher tolerance. 
       Furthermore, it would be very interesting to know that tolerance can also arise when alcohol modulates the expression of protein channels on the cell surface of neurons. Prior to exposure, there is an established balance among how these membrane proteins are produced, organized, recycled, and degraded, which is mediated by scaffolding proteins (Pietrzykowski & Treistman, 2008). When in contact with clusters of BK channels in presynaptic terminals, alcohol leads to separation and soon redistribute them between the membrane and cytoplasm. Simultaneously, the substance blocks the binding of scaffolding proteins to receptors, causing phosphorylation (addition of a phosphate group from ATP) of the channel subunits and slowly resolving the inhibition of receptors induced earlier (Pietrzykowski & Treistman, 2008). 
        These are some of the findings about how components of the neuronal membrane are involved in the development of tolerance upon exposure to a substance, though until this day, it is still unclear in determining which processes are the markers for a particular type. This is why more research is a necessity, but nevertheless they have given us an opportunity to gain a deeper understanding of how our cells respond to these harmful substances and, perhaps, appreciate our health more by controlling our drug use habits.



References
Pietrzykowski, A. Z., & Treistman, S. N. (2008). The molecular basis of tolerance. Alcohol research & health: the journal of the National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism, 31(4), 298–309.

nodes.title: Interesting Facts About Opioids and Hallucinogens! (Sy Thinh Nguyen)

typeData.textContent:
What are opioids? 
Opioids are a group of drugs that include heroin, morphine, methadone, codeine, and many more. As we have previously known, morphine is commonly prescribed to patients because it has analgesic effects, which acts to subside the pain experienced by patients. These drugs are derived from what is known as opium, a compound that is naturally found in poppy plants. 

How do opioids work exactly?
Once opioids enter the body, they will bind to opioid receptors throughout the body - receptors on nerve cells of the brain, spinal cord, and our internal organs. Once they bind to these receptors, they stop the pain signal travelling from the body to the brain, thus making the individual feel painless. 

Does our body produce opioids? 
Our body does produce endogenous opioids, such as beta- Endorphins. This neurotransmitter is responsible for decreasing pain and it also decreases tension or anxiety when we are mentally stressed. According to “Biochemistry, Endogenous Opioids” by Saraswati Satyanarayan Shenoy and Forshing Lui, endogenous opioids are necessary because they also serve to regulate food intake and protect the cardiovascular system ( Shenoy & Lui 2018). 

Where else can opioids be found? 
Opioids, especially codeine, can also be found in over the counter medicine such as cough-suppressants, anti-nausea, and anti-diarrhea. A small dose of codeine is often used because their analgesic effects on minor pain are extraordinary.  

What are the withdrawal symptoms of opioids? 
Withdrawing from opioids can have adverse symptoms that are very similar to severe flu and extreme fatigue. To alleviate the pain associated with withdrawing opioids, the individuals are given methadone, which is also a type of opioid that helps those individuals to slowly give up on the heavier drugs such as heroin. 

What are hallucinogens? 
Hallucinogens are drugs that induce hallucinations and anomalies in visual perception. Common hallucinogens are LSD (Lysergic acid diethylamide) and Mescaline, which act as agonists to serotonin receptors, specifically to serotonin 2a receptors, hence strengthening the effects resulting in hallucinations. Oftentimes, hallucinogens are split in 2 categories, and they are classic hallucinogens and dissociative hallucinogens. Both types have the same effects of hallucinations, but dissociative hallucinogens can cause a sensation of dissociating from the user’s body.

What do LSD trips feel like? 
Dr. Albert Hoffmann, a scientist who discovered LSD and accidentally absorbed the compound through the skin, thus experienced the first trip ever. He recounted that the trip was similar to the effects of schizophrenia, where he sees colours and varying images. The trip often lasts in the range of 8-12 hours depending on the individual. Several side effects can occur along with the usage of these drugs, such as increased heart rate, increased in sensitivity, nausea, and many more. 

Are there long term effects associated with doing hallucinogens? 
In the long run, users sometimes have what is known as Hallucinogen Persisting Perception Disorder (HPPD), which is flashbacks of visual anomalies experienced during the trip. These experiences can feel very unpleasant for the user because it can happen unexpectedly even years after the usage of the drugs. 

Sources 
 - National Institute on Drug Abuse; National Institutes of Health; U.S. Department of Health and Human Services

- Shenoy SS, Lui F. Biochemistry, Endogenous Opioids. [Updated 2018 Oct 27]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2020 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK532899/

nodes.title: Sleep Disorders: Insomnia (Tommy)
nodes.description: Insomnia

typeData.textContent: Insomnia is the most common sleeping disorders, It causes individuals to experience complications staying and falling asleep. There are many possible factors that may lead to insomnia. These factors include drugs, exercise, mental status, and bedtime routines. Most individuals will encounter symptoms at least three times a week. Many times individuals suffering from insomnia will have increased anxiety levels. Due to the increased anxiety levels, sleeping will be even harder to achieve and this will create an exhausting ongoing cycle. Chronic insomnia could potentially be associated with symptoms of depression as a result of feeling exhausted. There are several manners to treat insomnia, such as limiting the use of caffeine, increased exercise, or medications. If the treatments don’t work, there is Cognitive-behavioural therapy. This a type of psychotherapy used to target processes and problem behaviors. This type of therapy is very productive as it includes stress management and problematic behavior approaches.
